inventory.commentary: Includes idioms 'at one' and 'for one' Does NOT include pronominal one, e.g., 'one must not slurp one's coffee'.

sense.name: the smallest whole digit
sense.commentary: ONE[+quantity][+number][+digit] Note: 'one' is an attribute of an NP, or refers to the number (1) itself.
sense.examples: John knows how to count from one to ten in Hungarian. Sally is quite petite and wears a size one. Last night it was minus-one outside. I have only one page left to go in this novel. He has been complaining about his job from day one.

sense.name: a single entity, person or place
sense.commentary: ONE[+entity][+singular] Note: one is equivalent to another NP
sense.examples: He is the best one among the three violinists. Yes, that's the one I ordered. After one date Mary thought he was the one. (one date = sense 1, the one = sense 2) This is not the one I'm remembering.

sense.name: a unit of paper currency, a bill
sense.commentary: ONE[+currency][+paper][+dollar] Note: occurs naturally in the plural or singular
sense.examples: I've only got a one on me. John pulled out three ones, two fives and a twenty.

sense.name: in a state of harmony or agreement
sense.examples: Seeing sunrise on the mountain top made John felt at one with the world. They are hardly at one when it comes to deciding how to redecorate their home.

sense.name: as an example
sense.examples: I, for one, think we should stop pretending this marketing strategy has worked for us. Bob, for one, has decided to bicycle to work instead of driving.
